diff_hunk:
@@ -413,6 +429,275 @@ struct PadInput<GPUDevice, T, int, NDIMS> {
   }
 };
 
+// TPF stands for Tile size Posibility Frontier. It denotes the tile size
+// combinations that consume the most computational resources constrained by
+// number of threads per SM limit, shared memory limit and overall degree of
+// parallelism.
+// Tile size combinations lying on this frontier would achieve the maximum
+// utilization of available resources and combinations lying outside this
+// frontier is not performance-wise profitable or simply not possible.
+#define TPF_CHECKER(OP)                                                   \
+  size_of_t == 16 &&    (TileLongSide == 32   && (TileShortSide OP 4)  || \
+                         TileLongSide == 64   && (TileShortSide OP 4)  || \
+                         TileLongSide == 128  && (TileShortSide OP 4)  || \
+                         TileLongSide == 256  && (TileShortSide OP 2)) || \
+      size_of_t == 8 && (TileLongSide == 32   && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 64   && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 128  && (TileShortSide OP 8)  || \
+                         TileLongSide == 256  && (TileShortSide OP 4)  || \
+                         TileLongSide == 512  && (TileShortSide OP 2)) || \
+      size_of_t == 4 && (TileLongSide == 32   && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 64   && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 128  && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 256  && (TileShortSide OP 10) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 512  && (TileShortSide OP 4)  || \
+                         TileLongSide == 1024 && (TileShortSide OP 2)) || \
+      size_of_t == 2 && (TileLongSide == 32   && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 64   && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 128  && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 256  && (TileShortSide OP 10) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 512  && (TileShortSide OP 4)  || \
+                         TileLongSide == 1024 && (TileShortSide OP 2)) || \
+      size_of_t == 1 && (TileLongSide == 32   && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 64   && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 128  && (TileShortSide OP 15) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 256  && (TileShortSide OP 10) || \
+                         TileLongSide == 512  && (TileShortSide OP 4)  || \
+                         TileLongSide == 1024 && (TileShortSide OP 2))
+
+constexpr bool TileSizePossibilityFrontierCheck(int TileLongSide,
+                                                int TileShortSide,
+                                                int size_of_t, int mode) {
+  // When mode is 0, this function checks whether the tile size combination lies
+  // on the tile size possibility frontier. When mode is 1, it checks whether
+  // the combination lies outside the frontier.
+  return mode == 0 ? TPF_CHECKER(==) : TPF_CHECKER(>);
+}
body: I think it's probably worth the extra word to ensure the understanding that the frontier is defined in the context of a tile size space and is not the property of a certain tile size combination. And the term _possibility frontier_ is a time tested term used to convey such idea.
